text: October 20, 2000  -  Joint Meeting of the
label: BODY

text: Nonprescription Drugs & Gastrointestinal Advisory Committees
label: HH1

text: Food and Drug Administration
label: BODY

text: Center for Drug Evaluation and Research
label: BODY

text: Holiday Inn, 2 Montgomery Avenue, Gaithersburg, MD
label: BODY

text: Prilosec 1(omeprazole magnesium, Astra Zeneca & Procter & Gamble, NDA 21-229)
label: HH2

text: Currently, there are two classes of drugs, antacids and acid reducers (histamine-2 receptor antagonists),
label: BODY

text: available in the OTC market to treat heartburn.  Both antacids and acid reducers are indicated for the treatment
label: BODY

text: of acute occasional heartburn symptoms. The acid reducers have an additional claim for the prevention of meal
label: BODY

text: induced heartburn symptoms if ingested at specified times prior to a meal. At today’s meeting, the sponsor is
label: BODY

text: seeking the approval of omeprazole in the OTC setting for these indications and for the additional indication of
label: BODY

text: 24-hour prevention of heartburn.  Omeprazole, a proton-pump inhibitor, is currently indicated Rx for the
label: BODY

text: treatment of duodenal and gastric ulcer, symptomatic Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD), erosive
label: BODY

text: esophagitis, and pathological hypersecretory conditions.  In support of the proposed OTC marketing, the
label: BODY

text: sponsor conducted studies to evaluate the efficacy of omeprazole 10 mg and 20 mg for the treatment of acute
label: BODY

text: symptomatic heartburn (studies 092, 095, 017, 018, 019), for the prevention of meal induced heartburn (studies
label: BODY

text: 005 and 006) and for the 24 hour prevention of heartburn (studies 171 and 183).  They also conducted five
label: BODY

text: actual use studies (studies 003, 067, 014, 022 and 091) to evaluate consumer usage patterns and dosing
label: BODY

text: compliance.
label: BODY

text: A. In studies 092 and 095, the primary endpoint for efficacy was the occurrence of sustained complete relief of
label: BODY

text: the first treated episode of heartburn.  Based on the primary measure of efficacy, is there a clinically
label: BODY

text: significant improvement of acute symptomatic heartburn in either the 10 or 20-mg omeprazole groups
label: BODY

text: compared to placebo? Please explain your answer.
label: BODY

text: B. In studies 005 and 006, the primary endpoint for efficacy was the percentage of subjects heartburn-free over
label: BODY

text: the entire four-hour period after a provocative meal.
label: BODY

text: 1. Based on the primary measure of efficacy, is there a clinically significant improvement of heartburn
label: BODY

text: symptoms in either the 10 or 20 mg omeprazole groups compared to placebo?  Please explain your
label: BODY

text: answer.
label: BODY

text: 2. Are the analyses of the pre-specified secondary endpoints supportive of the primary study outcome?
label: BODY

text: Do they add information regarding clinically significant treatment effect?
label: BODY

text: C. In studies 171 and 183, the primary endpoint for efficacy was the complete prevention of heartburn between
label: BODY

text: the first two doses of therapy.
label: BODY

text: 1. Based on the primary measure of efficacy, is there a clinically significant improvement of heartburn
label: BODY

text: symptoms in either the 10 or 20 mg omeprazole groups compared to placebo?  Please explain your
label: BODY

text: answer.
label: BODY

text: 2. Are the analyses of the pre-specified secondary endpoints supportive of the primary study outcome?
label: BODY

text: Do they add information regarding clinically significant treatment effect?
label: BODY

text: D. Based on the types and frequency of adverse events reported in the clinical trials and in the post-marketing
label: BODY

text: adverse events database, are the safety concerns for the OTC marketing of omeprazole able to be
label: BODY

text: addressed solely by labeling (identifying risks) to consumers for (a) short term or (b) chronic intermittent
label: BODY

text: use? In answering this question, please consider the reports of anaphylaxis/angioedema/urticaria, liver
label: BODY

text: toxicity, white blood cell disorders and severe skin reactions.
label: BODY

text: E. Do other safety concerns affect acceptability of the OTC marketing of omeprazole? In answering this
label: BODY

text: question, please consider the questions raised by the FDA reviewer regarding: 1) the masking of serious
label: BODY

text: disease; 2) the potential for genotoxicity, tumorigenicity,  and fetal and developmental toxicity; 3) rebound
label: BODY

text: hyperacidity reported in the literature with discontinuation of therapy; and 4) hypergastrinemia that may be
label: BODY

text: associated with the chronic or chronic intermittent use of omeprazole.
label: BODY

text: F. Are there drug-drug interactions that affect acceptability of OTC marketing of omeprazole?
label: BODY

text: G. In the actual use studies, approximately 65% of the subset of subjects using the product only for the
label: BODY

text: prevention of heartburn exceeded the 10 consecutive day limit for dosing recommended on the label.
label: BODY

text: (Note: 19% to 22% of consumers using omeprazole for both acute symptoms and prevention similarly
label: BODY

text: exceeded the 10 consecutive day limit for dosing recommended on the label).  Do these results suggest that
label: BODY

text: omeprazole will likely be used by consumers on a chronic basis for conditions other than episodic heartburn
label: BODY

text: (e.g. GERD)?   Is the treatment of GERD an acceptable OTC indication?
label: BODY

text: H. Based on the results of the actual use and label comprehension studies, has the sponsor presented
label: BODY

text: adequate data to substantiate that consumers will be able to use omeprazole appropriately in the OTC
label: BODY

text: setting for: 1) acute symptomatic treatment; 2) prevention for up to 10 days.
label: BODY

text: In responding, consider these factors:
label: BODY

text: a) The ability of consumers to appropriately self-select.
label: BODY

text: b) The ability of consumers to use the correct dosage and for the period of time specified in the label.
label: BODY

text: c) The ability of consumers to identify when they should see a physician before using the product and
label: BODY

text: once they have begun using the product.
label: BODY

text: d) The ability of consumers to identify serious adverse events.
label: BODY

text: e) The ability of consumers to avoid interacting drugs.
label: BODY

text: Use in women of childbearing age or in the pediatric population.
label: BODY

text: Has the sponsor provided sufficient evidence to support the approval of omeprazole 10 mg and/or 20 mg for
label: BODY

text: use in the OTC setting for:
label: BODY

text: 1. Acute symptomatic heartburn?  Please explain.
label: BODY

text: 2. Prevention of episodic or chronic heartburn? Please explain.
label: BODY

text: a) If yes to either, are there any additional studies or risk management programs needed post-
label: BODY

text: approval?
label: BODY

text: b) If no, what additional studies or risk management programs are necessary to support approval for
label: BODY

text: OTC marketing?
label: BODY

text: J. If the Committee recommends approval of omeprazole for use in the OTC setting, please discuss any
label: BODY

text: recommendations regarding information to be conveyed in labeling (e.g., to help consumers select between
label: BODY

text: omeprazole and other currently available OTC products, and to help consumers use omeprazole safely and
label: BODY

text: effectively).
label: BODY
